newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian MinFins weaker on further freeze.
newsitem.headline: Russian MinFins weaker on further freeze.

text.p: Prices of Russian MinFin bonds eased on news of a further freeze of bonds by Russian police and dealers said on Friday prices could ease more in nervous trading but the decline was unlikely to be large.
A senior official at Vneshtorgbank, the main depositary for the bonds, said police in Russia's Samara region had frozen $10.6 million nominal of the fourth and fifth tranches of MinFin bonds.
Vneshtorgbank said on Thursday Moscow police had frozen MinFin bonds with a face value of $129,000 this month. The total nominal value of all MinFin bonds outstanding is $11 billion.
"The downward trend continued from yesterday," an ICFI Moscow Partners Bank dealer said. "All these freezes are creating uncertainty but today's price fall was not abrupt."
Over Thursday and Friday prices of the most actively traded fourth and fifth tranches fell around 1.5 point each on new freezes, dealers said.
"Prices could ease more but the extent may depend on clients' reaction," a London dealer said.
The ICFI Moscow Partners Bank dealer said prices could still edge down but they seemed to be close to the bottom and investors could find current levels attractive.
"After all, the market was firm after U.S. interest rates were not changed," he said.
The U.S. Federal Reserve announced on Tuesday that it would not change interest rates.
